intro: Ranunculus stipitatus, commonly known as the dwarf buttercup, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, often bright-colored flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters, with simple, alternate leaves that are usually deeply lobed. Its flowers are usually yellow or orange, with five to eight sepals that resemble petals. Ranunculus stipitatus prefers moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, woodlands, and stream banks.
